ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my skills in analyzing and performing French and German art songs.
I learned a lot about the lives and times of Wolf and Poulenc, and developed my skills as a pianist through transcription!
Understanding of the works of Francis Poulenc and Hugo Wolf, particularly in connection to major art and poetry movements of their times

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Lalli is an incredible strength of this course. He is kind, caring, absolutely brilliant, and would go to the end of the world for his students. He knows the world of art song inside and out, but hes always so excited to hear new takes on old classics. I do wish the course was a little more organized, though.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class relies on attending the seminars as they're happening, which makes it difficult for remote learning, especially with the musical component. However, the use of pre-recorded video submissions of student performances was a good adaptation.

Professor Lalli did a great job of adapting this course to a virtual format, as well as any music course can be. Though nothing is a substitute for live music, the recording format was well-organized, and the private lessons were a welcome supplement.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely  to a musician for sure. Though some non musicians took this course, it is definitely geared towards performers.

Yes! Professor Lalli gives so much time and attention to each individual student; he practically tailor-makes the class for the people in it. Each week, he prepares engaging slides with audio and visual interactive elements. If you are a musician (singer or not) with any interest in the intersection of art, music, and poetry, take this class!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture, as well as one on one virtual coachings with Professor Lalli and Sara.

extras.title:
MUSI 324 01
        Songs of Wolf and Poulenc
